PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 1902-3, 1 family - 3 bachelors.
   How many of these were bachelor's homes? From 1902-3, only 3.
   How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once a month.
   Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? On Sundays.
   Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? On Sundays.

2. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? No, until 1908. Most visiting was done without an invitation, sometimes invited.
   What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Morning, some time after noon.
   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Usually.

3. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) You were simply invited generously to stay for lunch, which was usually very good.
   If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Tea or coffee, sandwiches, fruit, parties.

4. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Usually whole family until 1908 or 1910.

5. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Bees for building, quilting, etc.
   Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.
   My husband had a bee to build a barn, then gave a barn dance, first at which was about 200 guests.

6. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.
   There were dances about twice a month in a house called Rollin big house, which had an unoccupied room, which allowed two square dances.
   Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.
   Not nearly so frequent.

7. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Usually each family entertained nights once during winter, if they had room for a dance, if not, they played cards.
REMEMBER VISITING, PARTYING, ETC.

1. This last few years, how many homes have you visited? How many of these were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? On what days?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? What was the reason?

4. How often did you go out to dinner? In the morning, afternoon, or evening?

5. Did you ever invite others to your home? If so, why?

6. Did you ever have parties at your home? If so, describe them.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, drives, or dances in homes? Describe.

8. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
7. Were there any additions or major alterations in the school later?
   If so, explain what these changes were, giving dates and explain the reason,
   (that is, was it because of an increase in number of pupils, or for extra convenience such as adding a porch or coal shed).

School was built in 1864. All timber. In 1913 it was sold to A. Weber who moved it to Benson
and a brick school was built on same site.

8. Is this first school building still in use? No -
   If not, give the reason, (burned, new school built, school closed because of lack of pupils, etc.). Give dates if possible.

As stated above.

9. Describe the window arrangement in the classroom, telling how many, how placed (all on one side, on two sides of room, etc.) whether provided with blinds, etc.

3 windows on each side - Blinds. About 20 pupils.

Was there any kind of lamp in the school, or other provision for artificial light? Explain.

10. Describe the school equipment, - desks, (kind and number), blackboards, maps, etc.

Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included only a comparatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

Co-operative Credit Co. organized in Benson in 1913. Farmers had stores according to amount of land owned, 10 acres being limit.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Each farmer paid $50 per share.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

In churches or in the schools.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

All games mentioned above except kites.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

All games mentioned were played at various times.
CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, etc.)?

All games played at home.

What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

All games played at home.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
Just skating and hockey.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
Checkers and cards.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
All the family.

Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
Not much time for games in summer months.

Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
They mostly built snowmen, deep trenches, etc.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?  
Give year and month if possible.  
1904.

26. Who organized it?  
Myself and two others.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
For the community.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
At Holmes Lake.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
Ball games.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
Table cloths spread on grass, people sat around it, all ate together.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
Annual fruit sandwiches, many kinds of salads, pies, cookies, tea, coffee, and lemonade.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
Started about three o'clock (3 P.M.), lasted until late evening. Then danced in Holmes Lake resort.
23. What winter games were played outside? For example, skating, sledding, etc.

24. Was there much fun in such games? Or was everything usually busy with some kind of work? Explain, preferably with examples.

25. Did children invent games connected with such things as buckets, boxes, empty cans, etc., or other objects or games in the neighborhood?

33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Outstanding particular

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Picnic was held at Hill Hall, sponsored by the Anglican Church. 1906. Foot ball, base ball was played. Tables were set in a new turn left and right by A. Wilson. Later picnic held at Shell school 1911.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Only change was that children came more numerous and a little older.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Men, women, and young people. Everyone usually took part.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Baseball.

What year? 1906.

How long did it continue? Still on.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Baseball was only game played in competition with surrounding districts.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Rink for skating and hockey. Later years, after 1914.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

First open skating rink built about 1925.

Used for skating and hockey.

Curling rink was built about 1917.
35. Describe the new features of your town which you remember as childhood.

36. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

37. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Yes, July 1st.

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). Community.

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

Not to my knowledge.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

Set of 15 volumes: R.L. Stevenson, Homes & Val
History of England, History of Germany, Vol. 2 & 3,
Vol. 1 History of Rome, about 58 other books.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Not any I know.

What kind of books and how many? Anglican Minutes, J.H. Lickley,
Brought books of various kinds.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? None to exchange.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. All Dickens,
& Natural History. (And too many to list.)

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? None.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates. United Church Sunday School
had a library of miscellaneous books.

48. Was there a school library? Yes. When was it begun? By Gift of Education.

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

Parents brought them home to read.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?

Quite often.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? Minneapolis Journal, Daily, West Farmer, Family Herald and Weekly Star, Western Mercury.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.
Came Minneapolis Journal of the first two years, got Family Herald instead.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? No
Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
All my books.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
Simply read all books I possessed over and over.

Musical Entertainment.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Organ.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Violins.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. Piano, and violin. The violin was taken away when daughter married.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

Dancing, singing was always enjoyed at church, also musical selections.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

There were some men, bachelors, met English who were very good singers.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

Too many & mention. But especially, what in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

The music played was what we played in the town and cities of Canada.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain. No

64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Music is used at dances, but also in homes, at noon Radio, today the place of musical home, hall used in church.
